instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight
threads.message:
Need some help please sorry.. ok so pin 1 at LCD connector I have 0v
<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> has pp5v__s0 going in. 
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_R</SIGNAL> is present going into <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>.

<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_SW</SIGNAL> is missing along with <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>

i have replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> and reballed a used <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> from donor board. 

Could the <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> be the problem here?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight
threads.message: Do you have imagen? Only no backlight?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight
threads.message: Was only no backlight but problem solved. I came in with a fresh mind and fresh eyes this morning. Spent 2 mins looking, changed the LCD cable and problem solved 15min total. Spent a good two hours last night testing and changing crap...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight
threads.message:
No intent to hijack here.. Just some curiosity:

Changing lcd cable requires prying off the bezel or top glass piece correct? How are you doing this without scratching the display itself. I puled a good LCD out of its housing without damaging it in order to throw it into a display with functional backlight. Got it in some how and misinterpreted Duke's instruction to re use original glue, clamp it and wait. Got to the last edge portion and good night nurse. 

I layed kapton tape around the border to negate cosmetic damage to the display.. What's the trick?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight
threads.message: The rMBP have the other side of the LVDS (or DP really I think) under the plastic cover. It's not under the glass like with the older <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> et al.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight
